triplets: Edible vegetable derived from the young shoots of the perennial Asparagus officinalis plant
Eating raw in salads, steaming, boiling, grilling, or cooking in various culinary dishes
Plant shoots consisting of tender stems and tips
Tender spear (shoot) which is the edible part
Tip containing tightly packed buds, often more flavorful than the stem
Green for standard varieties; white when grown underground to prevent chlorophyll formation
Asparagus plant, cultivated vegetable gardens, and agricultural production systems
Various farmers and horticulturists who cultivate asparagus commercially or domestically
Approximately 12–20 grams per spear depending on thickness and variety
Typically 15–30 cm per spear when harvested
Short-lived as a harvested vegetable (a few days to 1 week refrigerated); the plant itself is perennial and can produce spears for 15–20 years
